docs.lead_paragraph: Trading in the rapidly devaluing ruble came to a screeching halt yesterday, renewing concerns about Russia's ability to manage $40 billion in ruble-denominated debt, roughly 25 percent of which is held by foreign investors. But Western investors and banks could face greater losses from the complex financial instruments known as derivatives. Indeed, the amount of Russian derivatives at risk for foreign investors may be sharply higher than that of bonds and loans. While the lack of public disclosure make estimates difficult, some currency traders and emerging-market specialists have set the value of derivatives at risk in Russia as high as $100 billion. Many analysts, however, think the figure is probably much lower than that.
docs.abstract: While Russia's devalued ruble raises concerns about country's ability to manage its $40 billion in ruble-denominated debt, 25 percent of which is held by foreigners, Western investors and banks could face even greater losses from Russian derivatives; these complex financial instruments could pose greater risk becuse lack of public disclosure makes estimates of investments difficult; some currency traders and emerging-market specialists have set value of derivatives at risk in Russia as high as $100 billion, but many analysts believe figure is probably much lower than that; large American banks have relatively little exposure in Russia given their size--about $7.68 billion--but other undisclosed positions could add to banks' derivatives worries (M)
docs.snippet: Trading in the rapidly devaluing ruble came to a screeching halt yesterday, renewing concerns about Russia's ability to manage $40 billion in ruble-denominated debt, roughly 25 percent of which is held by foreign investors.    But Western investors...

docs.lead_paragraph: Childhood has not been kind to them, these four brothers and sisters. Their overwhelmed parents smacked them to keep them in line, counselors say, and the three oldest, now ages 10, 9, and 5, were sexually molested by their mother's brothers. Now angry and insecure, the siblings hit one another, made disturbing sexual gestures, sometimes wet their beds and misbehaved in school.

headline.main: Emphasis Shifts to Keeping Siblings Together When Using Foster Homes

docs.abstract: Foster care program in Chicago called Neighbor to Neighbor keeps siblings together; it reflects growing national movement in foster care; fueled by lawsuits in New York City, Chicago and elsewhere, states have begun enacting laws and establishing programs to encourage foster parents to care for several siblings; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a philanthropic gesture unusual in its size and purpose, two local foundations have come to the rescue of the Houston Symphony Orchestra, donating a total of $7.3 million, which will wipe out its accumulated budget deficit, the symphony announced today. The two donors, the Wortham Foundation, which has been the symphony's most significant benefactor, and the Houston Endowment, the largest grant-making foundation in the state, each gave $3.65 million.

headline.main: $7.3 Million Gift Rescues The Houston Symphony

docs.abstract: Wortham Foundation and Houston Endowment make unusual gift of $7.3 million to Houston Symphony, rescuing it by wiping out entire accumulated budget deficit (M)
docs.snippet: In a philanthropic gesture unusual in its size and purpose, two local foundations have come to the rescue of the Houston Symphony Orchestra, donating a total of $7.3 million, which will wipe out its accumulated budget deficit, the symphony announced...

docs.lead_paragraph: These days, Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross is everywhere a candidate for Governor ought to be, from Long Island to Niagara Falls, with one crucial exception: television. With just three weeks left until the Democratic primary, Ms. McCaughey Ross has yet to begin a large-scale advertising campaign, a lapse that has mystified political analysts and delighted her opponents. It has also raised serious questions about the willingness of her financier husband, Wilbur L. Ross Jr., to spend millions of dollars on the race.

headline.main: Candidate Is Everywhere but in TV Ads

docs.abstract: Political analysts are mystified that Lieut Gov Betsy McCaughey Ross, candidate for Governor, has not yet begun a large-scale advertising campaign with just three weeks left until Democratic primary; speculate that her husband, financier Wilbur L Ross Jr, may not be willing to spend millions of dollars on her campaign; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your Aug. 22 editorial on the ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit that Medicare beneficiaries enrolled in health maintenance organizations have a constitutional right to due process when they are denied services does not mention an important implication of the ruling: by defining Medicare H.M.O.'s as ''government proxies,'' the court dispelled the myth that these Government-created entities represent the free market at work. Like most H.M.O.'s, Medicare H.M.O.'s were created and are maintained by government fiat.

headline.main: Let Doctors Cut Cost of Medicine; Market-Ruled Medicare?

docs.abstract: Dr Brant S Mittler letter disputes August 22 editorial on ruling by US appeals court that Medicare beneficiaries enrolled in health maintenance organizations have constitutional right to due process when denied services (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 YELTSIN DISMISSES AIDES PUSHING ECONOMIC REFORM President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia dismissed his new team of economic reformers and reinstalled Viktor S. Chernomyrdin as Prime Minister, just five months after he derided Mr. Chernomyrdin as a spent force and cast him out of the Government. Mr. Yeltsin offered no explanation for his decision, which raised fresh doubts about the Kremlin's commitment to tough economic reforms and unsettling questions about President Yeltsin's ability to govern. A1 Senior Clinton Administration officials said they were troubled by President Yeltsin's decision, taken so close to a summit meeting between the two leaders scheduled for next week in Moscow. But a spokesman said that Mr. Clinton had decided to go ahead with his trip. Officials acknowledged that the move had caught them by surprise. A9

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: An Aug. 17 news article on the decline in the number of poor people enrolled in Medicaid in New York State noted that Medicaid directors may not want to draw attention to this development because the decline in caseload reduces the cost to city and state budgets, which in New York State require both the city and the state to contribute 25 cents for every dollar spent on Medicaid.
docs.abstract: Dr Katherine S Lobach letter on Aug 17 article holds enrolling eligible uninsured children in Medicaid would not greatly add to costs for New York State and its localities

docs.lead_paragraph: As automobile accidents go, it was not much: two teen-agers driving home from school in Southern California were bumped from behind. They later told investigators that they felt a little pain in their backs and necks. The day after the crash they went first, not to a doctor, but to a lawyer. The lawyer sent them to a clinic and the bills started to mount up. After two months the bills for one boy, 19, came to $3,740. For his friend, 14 years old, the cost was $4,090.

headline.main: Trying to Stem Auto Accident Fraud

docs.abstract: Allstate plans to sue dozen Southern California doctors and chiropractors and their assistants for $25 million for repeatedly overbilling auto accident victims or billing for services never provided in hundreds of cases over last few years; auto insurance experts say cases are part of widespread pattern of fraud by doctors and clinics across nation, who capitalize on real accidents by seeking payment for unneeded and never performed procedures; California suits are first of their kind by major insurer; Allstate says it is developing cases against doctors in other cities (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AT 10:45 A.M. yesterday, Mark Green was back on the steps of City Hall, this time releasing a report on the failures of state nursing homes. The news conference over, Mr. Green, a Democratic candidate for United States Senate, rested a sneaker against a railing and took stock of his Sunday morning. ''Five cameras,'' he said, gleaming, before bouncing into a car and heading for the first of two streets fairs. And this was a light day.

headline.main: Metro Matters; With Little to Lose, Mark Green Injects Issues Into Senate Race

docs.abstract: Adam Nagourney Metro Matters column discusses Mark Green's active public campaign for Democratic nomination for New York State Governor; photo (M)
